channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Put American on Trial
item.description: Matthew Todd Miller is accused of shredding his tourist visa and demanding asylum, which the North says is a “hostile act” against the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Cease-Fire in Ukraine Holds, but Soldiers and Residents Doubt It Will Last
item.description: The cease-fire between the Ukrainian government and Russian-backed separatists held on Saturday, but some violations were reported, and soldiers and civilians doubted that calm would prevail.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family prepared to flee their home in the southeastern Ukrainian village of Lebedinskoye after hearing explosions nearby.

item.title: Building Good Will in a Troubled Afghan District, but Not Without a Fight
item.description: A day trip to a troubled district with America’s elite troops and Afghan government and military officials was characterized by the absurd and unexpected, features of the war in the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off
item.description: China is set to become the world’s largest market for the fledgling space tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: By CAO LI
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheng Tianxing, a tea trader, bought a $100,000 ticket for a trip on a commercially operated flight to go 64 miles above Earth.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Refugees Reshape Their Camp, at the Risk of Feeling at Home
item.description: The construction of a public square in a deeply conservative Palestinian refugee camp has made some there feel more at home, a provocative concept in camps conceived as temporary.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children played in a plaza in Al Fawwar, West Bank. Public spaces like the plaza are almost unheard-of in West Bank camps.

item.title: Somali Militants Confirm Leader’s Death in U.S. Strike
item.description: The Shabab, the Qaeda-linked militant network in Somalia, confirmed that its leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, had been killed in an American airstrike.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Hostage Says One of His Captors in Syria Was French
item.description: A French journalist who was a hostage in Syria from July 2013 to Dec. 2013 identified a Frenchman as one of his captors.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pachinko Parlors Court Japan’s Youth
item.description: With new halls that are bigger, cleaner, more luxurious and friendlier, the pachinko industry is trying to reinvent itself by appealing to new customers and by cleaning up its image.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Evidence Grows of Russian Orthodox Clergy’s Aiding Ukraine Rebels
item.description: The Russian Orthodox Church has denied supporting separatist turmoil in Ukraine, but after rebels seized Slovyansk, evidence accumulated of close ties between the church and the pro-Russian cause.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining a road leading to a Russian Orthodox church in Slovyansk, Ukraine, are the graves of pro-Russian fighters who died fighting Ukrainian government troops.

item.title: Syrian Bombs Hit ISIS-Held Territory
item.description: At least 25 people, mostly civilians, were killed in the northeastern province of Raqqa as government forces attacked territory controlled by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The body of a man killed in Raqqa on Saturday by what residents said was an air attack by Syrian government forces.

item.title: Sierra Leone to Impose 3-Day Ebola Quarantine
item.description: Starting Sept. 19, citizens will not be allowed to leave their homes in a bid to prevent the disease from spreading and to allow health workers to identify cases in the early stages.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Malaysia Plans to Search Crash Site of Flight 17
item.description: Malaysia plans to send a search team to the Ukrainian crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 to gather physical evidence, its prime minister said.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia at a joint news conference with Tony Abbott, the Australian prime minister.

item.title: From a Texas Company to a Political Maelstrom in the Syrian Civil War
item.description: The director of operations for a Texas-based telecommunications company became interim prime minister of the Syrian opposition coalition.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER MURPHY
item.media:credit: Erin Trieb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suzanne Hitto, far left, said goodbye to her friend Sahar Ayad at a going away party in Murphy, Tex., in June.

item.title: Sierra Leone to Impose 3-Day Ebola Quarantine
item.description: In a bid to prevent the disease from spreading and to allow health workers to identify cases in the early stages, the authorities are forbidding citizens from leaving their homes starting Sept. 19.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: White House Memo: As Crises Pile Up, a President Sticks to His Deliberative Approach
item.description: President Obama’s determination to move deliberately and line up support from allies before confronting threats means that he has sometimes appeared to be a spectator to events outside his control.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama during a news conference in Tallinn, Estonia, on Wednesday.

item.title: 100 Die in 5 Days of Flooding in Northern India
item.description: Swollen and swift-moving rivers in the northern Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir force thousands of displaced people into relief camps.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Kashmiri residents fled to higher ground during floods on the outskirts of Srinagar on Saturday.

item.title: Afghans Say Taliban Are Nearing Control of Key District
item.description: Local Afghan officials say more than 200 police officers and soldiers have been killed during a fierce Taliban offensive in Helmand Province.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: North Korea Reported to Test Short-Range Missiles
item.description: North Korea fired three short-range projectile off its east coast that landed harmlessly in the sea near Japan, South Korean military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Politician Wins Spying Case in Germany
item.description: Germany’s domestic security watchdog must purge all files it has kept on a politician from an opposition party with roots in the former East Germany, a court said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Hague Prosecutors Ask to Delay Opening of Kenyan President’s Trial
item.description: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday asked for another delay in starting the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, saying that they could not proceed because the government had so far refused to hand over most of the information they had requested.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Toronto Mayor Called to Testify in Canada
item.description: Rob Ford, the mayor of Toronto, told reporters on Friday that he had been subpoenaed to testify at a court hearing related to efforts by his unofficial driver to recover a video showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Quick History: A 65-Ton Dinosaur as a Distraction From NATO, Ukraine and ISIS
item.description: The important news was the convergence of a NATO summit meeting, the beginnings of a cease-fire in Ukraine and the commitment to destroy ISIS.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: Leaders and senior ministers from 60 countries met for two days last week in Newport, Wales, to discuss the Ukraine situation and the ISIS threat.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Rare Outbreak of Dengue Fever in Japan
item.description: Japan’s health minister on Friday urged the public not to panic after a popular park in central Tokyo was closed because of a rare outbreak of dengue fever.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Obama Enlists 9 Allies to Help in the Battle Against ISIS
item.description: President Obama escalated the response to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria on Friday, recruiting allies to help crush the group and outlining a strategy that echoes the war on terror.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Iran Fails to Address All Nuclear Concerns, U.N. Says
item.description: Prospects for an agreement over Iran’s nuclear program appeared to suffer a setback when a United Nations monitoring agency said the Iranians had yet to meet two measures to ensure that their activities are peaceful.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN HARNEY
